section.title: Introduction to Ethical Imperatives
section.para: Ethics are individual or shared moral principles that govern our behavior and set standards for what is considered right or wrong. These moral principles can be applied to any component of human behavior, including personal, social, and economic or business decisions. Many organizations and businesses have internal ethical codes and guidelines for employees to follow when working , including medical and Standards Development Organizations (SDOs). [1] As our team continues efforts towards Integrated Knowledge Management (IKM) and a contributed IKM application, it is critical that our work improves the interoperability and quality of healthcare data to support medical professionals and patients with ethical considerations.

section.title: Medical Ethics
section.para: The medical field is driven by a strong code of Medical Ethics, or bioethics, that guide providers through their daily practice, decision making, and issues related to patient care. There are four pillars of medical ethics that guide providers as they determine the best course of action for patient care:

listitem.para: Autonomy (giving the patient the freedom to choose freely, where they are able)

section.para: Unlike other fields, medical providers and other professionals involved in patient care are often faced with moral decisions that have unique consequences for not only patients, but also for the patient’s family, communities, and even themselves. The Hippocratic Oath may come to mind when thinking about ethics in patient care. This 5th century Code of Ethics advanced the idea of relieving patient suffering and promoting well-being through patient-physician relationship and still guides providers today. The American Medical Association’s Code of Medical Ethics is another ethical guide for providers that was adopted in 1847; this code explains the standards of ethical conduct for physicians, patients, and the entire medical profession/society. The current Code has greatly expanded since 1847 and offers general rules of practice as well as providing tools for physicians facing novel ethical questions. [3]

Patient care providers are not the only medical professionals that encounter scenarios that raise ethical questions surrounding the care they provide, professionals involved in medical research also face ethical dilemmas, like which patients qualify for experimental treatments. The medical community created institutional review boards to address ethics in research and develop guidelines and solutions for these questions.

section.title: The Impact of Healthcare Terminologies on Ethics
section.para: An ongoing and developing conversation in medical ethics is the proper use of health data. Genomics is an example of a data source that produces large volumes of health data. The field of Genomics uses whole genome or whole exome sequencing extracted from biological specimens to study genetically linked diseases, population wide health, and rare or neglected diseases. However, while this data offers researchers quality insight, the use of this data opens the door to questions about patient consent, data storage and future use, and breaches in patient privacy. To manage, codify, and communicate the large amounts of health data they collect, healthcare organizations use healthcare terminology standards like Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine Clinical Terms© (SNOMED CT©), Logical Observations Identifiers Names and Codes© (LOINC©), and National Library of Medicine’s codification of the U.S. pharmacopeia (RxNorm) developed by SDOs. Although SDOs continuously improve their codes, many terminology standards lack interoperability between the standards themselves and the organizations that use them, which can impact patient safety and the quality of care.

section.title: Ethical Implications for Providers
section.para: Beyond facilitating communication, healthcare terminology standards play a crucial role in medical ethics. In an environment where every decision holds weight, these terminologies work to ensure that healthcare professionals share a common understanding of patient data so that providers can translate information into actionable insights and improved patient outcomes. Making informed decisions is a critical component of a medical professional’s ethical responsibility. Electing for a given treatment option without understanding critical factors like existing health conditions, medical history, or other pertinent information can have both ethical and qualitative impacts on patient care. As efforts continue towards successful IKM, data must be seamlessly exchanged within and between systems, while maintaining meaning and accuracy, to prevent misunderstandings and errors and fulfill a provider’s ethical duty to “do good” and “do no harm”.

Furthermore, these terminologies play a role in addressing challenges related to health equity, including fairness and accessibility in healthcare. Terminology standards provide a normalized and repeatable way to classify conditions, treatments, and various other aspects of patient care. As we work to improve the interoperability and accuracy of transmitted data through IKM, researchers and providers will more easily be able to identify and address discrepancies in healthcare. Standardized terminologies are instrumental in dismantling barriers that stem from linguistic, cultural, or systemic differences by providing a universal language for health conditions and treatments to support consistent care, irrespective of a patient or provider's background or geographic location. Healthcare terminologies promote a shared understanding of conditions and treatments across groups of people, reducing disparities in healthcare delivery. Standardized terminologies benefit clinicians in the same way by providing them with an unbiased language to navigate the world of clinical decision making and potential ethical dilemmas. [4]

section.title: Ethical Implications for Patients
section.para: The ethical implications of patient comprehension are profound. In scenarios where treatment options are complex or risky, the ability of patients to understand and weigh these options is critical. Healthcare terminologies work to convey information in a consistent and clear manner, reducing the likelihood of misunderstandings that could impact patient decisions [4,5,6]. These terminologies serve as key facilitators in enhancing patient communication and autonomy. By providing a clear and consistent language for health information, they empower patients to understand their health better, participate actively in their care, and make informed choices – all fundamental to ethical and patient-centered healthcare.

Ethical patient care, including informed patient decision making, must remain a driving force behind IKM. Ensuring that data, clinical concepts, and terminologies are standardized and interoperable between and within systems like EHRs, patient portals and educational materials can lead to improved patient comprehension, better self-management of conditions, reduced hospital readmissions, and the ability for patients to ultimately choose their care. [5]

section.title: Conclusion
section.para: Ethical considerations must remain a driving force behind the development, implementation, and adoption of IKM. IKM must support providers and patients as they navigate existing ethical dilemmas, while balancing the ethical concerns surrounding patient data, personally identifiable information, and personal health information use and storage. IKM will also need to rapidly integrate with new technologies to address ethical considerations, particularly around privacy and consent, as artificial intelligence, machine learning, and other technologies become more prominent in the healthcare ecosystem.
